content: My guess is the account is POP. highlight account name in left pane, rightclick and select 'settings'. From there, click 'server settings' and check what you have set for retention. Regarding the other account, my guess is that account is IMAP, with all messages retained online.
creator: davidsk

content: Fortunately, since the account is IMAP, the message still exist. You should be able to view online and confirm that. The simple approach might be to just delete the account and reconstruct it.
creator: davidsk

content: When you create a new profile, Thunderbird uses it. That doesn't mean the prior profile disappeared. You can ceck to see what other profiles are set up by clicking help>moretroubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles' in left pane and click 'about:profiles. That screen will show what profiles are there. The prior profile, if not deleted, should appear and you can click to activate it.

content:
mikolaj.kurczewski said
Hello. Is it possible to transfer the log with the saved filtered mail filters from one computer to another computer? Where would I find the path to this LOG? Thank you in advance for your help. Greetings, long-time user of Mozilla solutions.

The filterlog.html file and msgFilterRules.dat file are stored in the account subfolder of the Mail or ImapMail subfolders of the profile folder, e.g. in ImapMail/imap.gmail.com or Mail/pop.aol.com. The files can be copied between accounts on the same or different computers.
creator: sfhowes

content: Your addresses are stored in files on your harddrive. If your colleagues are also using Thunderbird at a similar release level, you could share the actual files with them. But my guess is that isn't your intent. Another low-tech approach would be to extract your address book to a csv file and email that to them. If you want yourself and colleagues to share live updates, then you need to get your addresses online, such as carddav with a google account that each person sets up individually. But that takes time for each individual. There is no simple, quick, solution. I suggest going with the csv file for now, and then reassess with colleagues on how you all want to proceed long-term.
creator: davidsk

content: Does it happen in safe/troubleshoot mode, (hold Shift when launching TB)? Is hardware acceleration enabled in Settings/General, when in normal mode?

content: When you import from a file, which I assume you did. Particularly a CSV file the process asks you to verify that the selected columns are mapped to the correct data. My guess is you did not complete that step, so should do it again and this time ensure the fields are correctly mapped to the correct columns.

content:
Ciao, nativamente questa funzione non mi risulta disponibile.

Esiste un componente aggiuntivo denominato EMail Address Crawler https://addons.thunderbird.net/it/thunderbird/addon/email-address-crawler/ che svolge questa funzione, tuttavia non sembra compatibile con le versioni recenti di Thunderbird.

Cercando in rete si trova un programma di terzi noto come 'Thunderbird Email Data Extractor' che dovrebbe fare ciò che chiedi. Però non sembra essere più aggiornato, non so dirti se funziona ed è a pagamento. Lo trovi ad esempio qui https://www.softpedia.com/get/Internet/E-mail/Mail-Utilities/Thunderbird-Email-Data-Extractor.shtml

Una via alternativa è quella di usare MBOX Email Extractor che trovi ad esempio qui https://www.softpedia.com/get/Internet/E-mail/Mail-Utilities/MBOX-Email-Extractor.shtml

In questo caso devi anzitutto fare una copia del profilo di Thunderbird https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo Devi poi fare copia dei file MBOX che contengono la posta e farli analizzare da MBOX Email Extractor

  • I file mbox sono file senza estensione. I loro nomi coincidono con i nomi delle cartelle predefinite di Thunderbird (in inglese): inbox (in arrivo), sent (inviate), trash (cestino), junk (spam), etc.
  • Se sono state create nuove cartelle o sottocartelle, ad ognuna di esse sarà associato un nuovo file mbox con il nome della cartella stessa. Similmente se si è usata la funzione Archivia di Thunderbird per suddividere la possta per anno o mese
creator: @next

content: OK, I'm just guessing here on what you're describing. I'm guessing the send folder may be threaded and your message isn't appearing as anticipated. You can check that by highlighting the Send folder and then clicking View>Sort By and looking to see if Threaded has a checkmark by it. If so, tick Unthreaded which will reset the sort order of the folder. If that works, great. If not, then the problem lies elsewhere.
creator: davidsk

content: Most users, when they want to send an already sent message, use Edit As New Message from the context menu. Try that and see if the resulting sent message appears in the Sent folder.

content:
re : I actually am storing my local files on Dropbox

Computer : Is the operating system 32bit or 64 bit?

Thunderbird: Are you using a win32bit or win64bit version?

There used to be a limit of up to 4GB on file, but I though this effected 32bit and Pop. Or perhaps you running FAT32 filesystem - maybe a partition formatted as FAT32 ?

Otherwise I thought the 4GB limit had been removed as of version 52.

For folders that get that error message - what type of mail account are they located in? Are you talking about folders in a POP or an IMAP mail account or in the 'Local Folders' mail account?

Do you mean you have set up your Thunderbird profile in Dropbox - meaning it is not in the default location?

Menu icon > View > Layout > select 'Folder Pane columns' This appears at the top of the Folder Pane and you will see a Name column. Right click on 'name' column and select 'Size' OR click on the small icon on the right to see drop down and Enable the 'Size' column

What is the size of the folder(s) which is/are triggering that 'not enough disk space' error message?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
As far as I am concerned any profile files that are in a synced location like you say you are using for drop box is an unsupported configuration. Change that to a non synced setup and see if that fixes the issue.

The issue will not be the fire size or free space, it will be Thunderbird can't access the file because it is locked for syncing post the last update 10 seconds ago.

Dropbox is not supported at all because a setup using it will fail. It is only a matter of time. Network shares are troublesome on gigabyte networks but technically supported. Dropbox is not.

If you think the developers need to support using cloud storage for local files, I suggest you use the feedback link on the help menu to flag your desire. Personally I just leave on the IMAP server what I want to synchronize in the cloud space.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: How do you access the Google Calendar? Thunderbird supports CalDAV natively by now, so no add-on is needed anymore.
creator: christ1

content:
Thanks again. 1) If I understand what you are asking,

- I access the calendar via Thunderbird with the api: googleapi://XXXX@XXXX.com/?calendar=XXXXX%40XXXX.com as per the screenshot. This is following instruction for adding a google calendar here: https://www.lifewire.com/how-to-sync-google-calendar-with-thunderbird-4691009 - I can also interface with the Google calendar directly from browser.

2) As to accessing the calendar natively, can I delete “Provider for Google Calendar?” Mozilla still seems to recommend using it for 2-way sync, but could just be something not updated. Maybe delete that and start over?
creator: Bus275Mail

content:
This is following instruction for adding a google calendar here:

While the Provider add-on should still work (assuming you're using the latest version), it's not needed anymore.

Maybe delete that and start over?

That's what I'd suggest.

  • Delete the Google Calendar in Thunderbird, and remove the Provider add-on. Restart Thunderbird.
  • Then: File (Alt-F) - New - Calendar
  • On the Network - enter your Gmail email address as Username, leave Location blank
  • enter your credentials when prompted, and give permission for Thunderbird to access your Google Calendar
  • make sure to allow cookies in Thunderbird before starting the authentication process. Cookies can be disabled afterwards
creator: christ1

content:
1. Is the server identified in your account settings as mail.optusnet.com.au? It is rather odd that the error mentions the IP address if your settings use the correct server name.
  2. Is the connection security set to None as designated by Optus. (Rather odd for a company that has already been hacked to be enforcing plain text communications, even in their own network.)
  3. Are you connecting to the mail server using an Optus internet connection?

Note: Reinstalling Thunderbird is almost certainly not going to work as the issue is in communications with the server (it is timing out) not in the installation on your device.

Unfortunately I feel Optus support is about as poor as that offered by Telstra (I am about done with them). Neither appear to offer folk that actually know anything about email.

if I dismount the drive and close thunderbird

Wrong sequence. First close Thunderbird, then umount the drive.

Thunderbird has not been properly shut down, so you probably need to remove the profile lock file. https://kb.mozillazine.org/Profile_in_use
